It can be safer to use other types of "spicy math". Still of the recent post-quantum standards NIST used as case study, 2 are already broken. So I guess we're still developing it. 

Classic cryptography is still very much good enough.

2. quantum tech.

Ok, I know, it's like way out there. But if classic cryptography and quantum are on opposite sides, there's a post-quantum algo that exists in between. https://t.co/7TrHG0YSnl

Obviously this is more than just blockchain and crypto. Basic cryptography in your day-to-day application uses this. If we can figure out the pattern of how prime numbers are "created", we can break cryptography much faster.
And why is that important? Because again, lots of cryptography these days are dependent on prime numbers. The non-factorisation of numbers allow us to create new and complex private-public key pairs.

1. Fast way to find prime numbers. 

And of course, there's a prize for this. It's the The Riemann Hypothesis.

Basically the idea is, if you can solve for the hypothesis, we can add all the numbers that touches a specific line, we can figure out all prime numbers.

Classic cryptography is dependent on us not solving for prime numbers. Then we can create what they call "spicy math" with elliptic curve and other really math.

Back to the earlier tweet, because in the digital space, people can move between economies (ie countries) easily.

Another similar game comes along, be it Zed Run, Pegaxy, or some other similar game. When assets become inflationary expensive and growth stops/significantly reduced - which is highlighted in the market price of the tokens - users are likely to move to another economy.

2. Application time. Let's do GameFi. 

Say, Axie Infinity as an economy. The growth was driven by increase in users entering the game. And there was inflation in prices of $AXIE hence the scholarship model.
Inflation enhances the attractiveness of networks.

So when networks (ie. economies, countries) reduce in value creation, and all other things equal, another network is creating value, the another network becomes more attractive to people to participate.
Networks exist because they create value through trade. See this thread https://t.co/TwSNgsym3L
When the value created by the network decreases, the rise in cost of things in the network becomes hard to afford.

In the physical world: moving country is hard. 

In the digital world: moving country is easy. Countries are basically networks and economies created by having a community of people coming together to interact.

1. Explanation

Simple words: country A stops growing (creating value) but prices of goods keep rising. Comparing A to country B who is growing, with the same rising prices of goods, country B is more attractive. 
Thus, people flock to country B.
I say game economy not defi protocol, because games are complex with heterogenous demand/supply functions than defi protocols.

TLDR: when you are building your #GameEconomy, make sure value creation is high compared to your competitors (other similar games), and that your monetary policy is working to balance the inflation in your economy.

You can't be inflating or deflating all the time.

Concept: When an economy loses the growth race (as opposed to substitute economies), inflation difference will cause said economy to lose network effects.

We designed @playSHRAPNEL looking at dynamic systems in mind. We designed the mechanisms to allow players to interact and then tested them out with various loops and measuring the sustainability of the loops.
This is super critical because everyone thinks that when you define the â€œtokenomicsâ€ (wtv that word means), your system is static and deterministic. It is the furthest from that

Another thing to note is that dynamic systems are kinda like deterministic complex systems. You canâ€™t predict what happens. 

!!! But you can run your Monte Carlo to explore the various outcomes unfolding.
And the key to all of that? Information. Information to reduce time lag between agents interacting within your system.
More info to come soon. Basically the most crucial determinant is not the mechanisms but itâ€™s function/purpose when people interact with the said mechanisms.

That means, everyone can build systems. Some systems are less wrong than others.

But can everyone maintain it? Iâ€™d say no. And that is key to success. Maintaining resilient systems.
And this is why key to success is not â€œsend me your white paper so I can understand the token economicsâ€. The key to success is the maintenance of these behavioural patterns by agents over time.
In systems, we want to design, understand and measure the structure  (ex-ante) and behaviour (ex-post) to study the results and improve behavioural patterns.
A protocol is just a system with some interactions governed in code like smart contract.

What examples of the first principle weâ€™re talking about here? 

1. Everything is a system. It is affected in a dynamic not static way
2. They are interconnected (coordination & collaboration btn agents)
3. Incentives, mechanisms and rules affect the way agents interconnect
Itâ€™s counterintuitive, of course. first principle IS first principle. Itâ€™s an axiom. The risk is then using the correct first principle on a wrong situation. Thatâ€™s the risk.

The beautiful thing is that everything we do when designing and maintaining protocols, we pretty much follow the same first principles in the company. One stone killing many birds. But it does put the all the risk in one basket. If the first principle is wrong, itâ€™s all fucked.

In token econs, Iâ€™m still working on defining the properties. Itâ€™s still very new and Iâ€™m waiting for more time to pass to show us whatâ€™s the necessary conditions. My hunch is around allocation, governance execution to remove bad actors and something around qualifying the network

In crypto econs, you typically look for correctness, liveness and privacy. we call these #conditions. Correctness is ALWAYS there. Liveness and privacy depend on what youâ€™re building and the necessary conditions.
I cannot emphasise enough that THESE ARE VASTLY DIFFERENT PROBLEMS TO SOLVE. Different methodologies, solutions and outputs.

For context, BFT = Byzantine fault tolerance. Web3 uses it. Or CEPS = circuit evaluation with passive security. Cryptography uses it. 

(Iâ€™m not smart enough to understand the math behind these protocols. But these are examples where crypto econs at layer 1/2 come in)

Anyway, #robustness is not about knowledge but influence. If itâ€™s knowledge, itâ€™s privacy we talk about. Influence is economics. 

We need to design protocol (crypto econs) and systems (token econs) to work regardless of adverse influence.

A ğŸ’¡ moment: crypto economics is about robustness amongst parties on the input and function. Token economics is about robustness amongst behaviours on the parties and function. 

!!! Thatâ€™s it !!! How that is defined in math, idk yet. But the crypto economics part is #BFT

Here, like a country, a platform can go through economic busts and booms, recession, financial crisis and hyperinflation.
The platform layerâ€™s goal is to increase economic transactions as that is a proxy for value creation. The economics is to maintain the right incentives and allocation of resources.
Where you find this? in the platform application layer. Metaverse, DeFi
The goal of token economics is to answer: given these constraints and goal, what kinds of economic transactions and resources can we design to achieve coordination properties we want?
Token economics is the study of designing incentives of the system to encourage economic transactions with the goal of coordinating and collaborating between agents in the system.
The economics is to the economics of validating information or messages.
The goal is to minimise adversary attacks.
In the infrastructure layer, the goal is to secure the integrity of information and protect the information against adversary actions.
Where you find this? in the infrastructure layer
The goal of crypto economics is to answer: given these constraints and goal, what kinds of incentives can we design to achieve the desired properties we want?
This can include messages being transferred like Ethereum, or information being kept like Filecoin.
Crypto economics is the study of designing embedded incentives of the system to hold desired properties with the goal of validating and agreeing on messages and information transacted in the system.

then, artists relied entirely on wealthy patrons (eg Medici family)

now, (nft) artists can rely on DAOs - a group of  individuals - to determine allocation of resources (funds). Like @PleasrDAO & @0xIreneDao

1. beginning of collective society
2. beginning of individuality and start of western-modernity as we know it now 
3. back to collective society for public goods, a start of a new type of modernity

Evolution: 

1. religion as coordination tool in society
2. civilisations, rule of law, capitalism as coordination tool
3. systems (smart contracts, economic policies) as coordination infrastructure and tokens as tool to enable coordination

War: when groups coordinate over limited resources. This can be internally or externally.

6/n In the same vein, Valkyrie Protocol selects for the wrong agents in the protocol.
5/n The insurance selects for the wrong people (agents) to begin with.

4/n What is adverse selection? 

If all medical insurance is the same price, people who have a history of medical issues (eg smokers) are more likely to buy insurance. The insurer will end up losing money, since the only people buying will need coverage.

3/n However, the problem here lies not in the token model and token design, but in the incentives of the agents. 

What we call, adverse selection in economics.

2/n Valkyrie Protocol is what they call "activation protocol". Think of them as third-party marketing arms of existing protocols to bootstrap their network. 

The native token (VKR) uses a burn and distribute funciton.

1/n In token economics, we are creating economic policies to align incentives. The thing is, incentives makes sense if the overall market is sound.

Inspired from: some opinion of Lee Kwan Yew when it comes to China VS USA global presence in the near future

TLDR: mining to maintain accounting record is cheaper than spending money on defence or attacking nations. 

Hence, crypto is actually not that expensive in the grand scale of things.

And the cost of defence is sooooo much. So to compare the cost of fiat vs Bitcoin or other crypto, itâ€™s not the actual production but the bigger macro market of how the economics work and how the value of currency is captured.
The sustainability of the economy and hence currency, is not just from monetary policy but also the ability to project power in military and warfare. Why do you think they spend so much on defence?

Then thereâ€™s fiat. USD, GBP, etc. It does represent the strength of the economy. 

â€œThe cost to maintain integrity of the dollar is in the monetary policyâ€ WRONG

â€œThatâ€™s so expensive and waste of electricity for Bitcoin to be mining nothing.â€ Yes I hear you. This is important to maintain the integrity of the coin. 

We come back to this later

Easy start: DLT currency. You can say itâ€™s Bitcoin, cryptocurrency, whatever.

The cost to maintain that is in the economics design & verification.
When we think of the cost to produce currency, it is not just the means or production but in itself the way to sustain, maintain and balance the value of the currency.

A case of fiat vs distributed ledger currency.

That is the future we're building. Robustness of a system that leverages both machines and humans coming together. We have the tech to create the tools. We have history with lessons. We have answers in nature. lfg. (9/9)

Only through observation can we tell where we are today and what changes are required for tomorrow. 

Governance can solve that. We just need the right tools in place. We can coordinate for better outcomes. With the right tools.
This is also important because a token is *LIVE*. It is 100% okay to improve the token mechanism every so often. E.g. bootstrapping state vs growth state vs steady state

What do we observe? 

The fundamental mechanisms and how it works in the system today, and what can be improved. 

Without observation and following a few key influences, that doesnt solve #decentralisation.
Observation changes how we behave. And that is key to solving the problem of governance.

In the same vein, the ability to observe a token-based ecosystem is key to understanding how to interpret the token and economy.  And that will be key to appreciating the difference between individual behaviour and collective system-wide behaviour.

The underlying key is that observation alone changes how we interpret the same thing.

Q: Is light a wave or a particle?
A: Yes.

Light is both a wave and a particle. They are 2 different ways of classifying the same thing. This is important because the way we classify things affects our analysis and interpretation of things.

(5/n) Anyway, fiscal discipline (mechanism design) is good because monetary policy (token design) affects the incentive (currency/token). And fiscal policy constrains economic agents' behaviours in the ecosystem.

(4/n) At the same time, the fact that one can exit the ecosystem easily makes it a more socially-binding constrain to create the mechanisms to benefit everyone. This becomes the "re-election fear of politicians" in code.

(3/n) In TradFi, it's easy to expand and borrow like crazy. #keynesian y'know. But to contract, politicians are afraid of backlash. Raise taxes and not be re-elected? nah.

In DeFi, the contraction is programmed in the token or ecosystem, which keeps the system more disciplined
(2/n) Why is that important? because mechanism design (aka gov policies) are impt in shaping the economy. And it governs people's behaviours in the system, which is reflective in the token value.

(1/n) One difference between DeFi and TradFi is the over-collateralisation factor. (I think @Arthur_0x and @HughKarp tweeted about it before)

This means that the mechanisms are backed by other assets, which instils fiscal discipline in the protocols.

Objectives in an ecosystem/economic (choose): 
1) sustainability
2) stability
3) growth

they are not the same. and they affect the incentive mechanisms (aka gov policies) to achieve those goals. without clearly defined goals, you can throw the token/currency away. pointless.

Economic lesson to learn from this episode: 

1. Game theory
2. Think in secondary effects
3. Dynamic engineering

TLDR on economics mechanism analysis: understanding the secondary and tertiary effects of the direct incentives, the analysis doesn't fall too far from economics 101. 

That is supply, demand, willingness to buy/sell, incentives, punishments and behaviours

Economics mechanism analysis: 

1. Mechanism design: free alpha, free $TRIBE, direct incentives
2. Economics 101: $TRIBE supply, willingness to sell $FEI, willingness to buy
3. Community vs VC: information asymmetry, #FUD
3. Quadratic fees: Direct incentives are used to reward and punish users in the system. Incentives are calculated at ($1 - trading price) ^ 2
2. DEX liquidity mechanism: The protocol owns part of the assets as part of governance to manage that $1 peg.

Where it went wrong:

FEI had great ideas in the pure #engineering side of the mechanism design.

But #economics is not pure systems engineering. It includes human interaction, which can make or break an ecosystem.

The human element is what separates engineering from economics.

What happened:

1. $FEI algo stablecoin
2. Raised $1.3b in ETH
3. Interesting mechanism design
4. Within 24h launch, price dropped significantly (60% loss)
5. Currently figuring out how to resolve it

Economics mechanism of $FEI â¬‡ï¸

TLDR: A great experiment!
Brings in features of DeFi â€” bonding curve, quadratic fees and DEX liquidity mechanism.
Great to experiment by bringing them together. However, more analysis and modelling could have been done.

Reselling and profitable: 

1) short term: when it hasnt reached market equilibrium from the demand or supply side
2) long term: more on the demand side in the long run (see tweet about for demand side variables)

NFT releases: 

1) auctions: reaches market equilibrium
2) open additions: reaches market equilibrium
3) draws: does not always reach market equi

Determining if NFT is worthy of flipping or not: 

1) demand: community (network effects, thickness in the token economics framework), utility (still underrated), social sentiments (hype)
2) supply: scarcity, inflationary aspects (in-community inflationary vs crowding out effect)

Here, I sit down w my mum to run through how the bitcoin system works ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ https://t.co/X1aBl4ZbkR
The longer chain wins. That means the longer chain is the "correct" chain. And the short chain's transactions will be added back so it will be confirmed in a new block on the long chain.

When a transaction is checked and validated, it is added to the block and form a chain. 

Sometimes, the chain split. Because 2 transactions are validated. But this split doesn't last for long. At the end, as more blocks are added, one is longer than the other.

ELI-highschool: Bitcoin's system uses this thing in economics called schelling point. That means a natural point people go towards. Aka long chain

Bitcoin's system is a chain of blocks. Inside the block, you have details about the transactions. (The world wide accounting system)
This happens often. It's just how the system works. It reorganises itself and at the end, you can't spent on both your cake and eat the ice cream too.

Now, where is the problem in this?

It *SEEMS* like someone spent $10 to buy ice cream AND cake. That's bad.

REALITY: because of the decentralised system to "check" your spending, this happens often. If one person checks that you spend on ice cream, you can't spend it on cake.

ELI5 Bitcoin's system: think of it as a world wide accounting system. It can see where the money is spent (not who).

Feature? No double spend. E.g. I can't spend the same $10 to buy $10 ice cream AND $10 cake.

How? Miners in a decentralised system to "check" spending.

3) asymmetric addition. 
We talked about this in Bancor. Sifchain uses this in a different way. The system auto-balances itself when asymmetric liquidity is added. Aka I only want to add $LISA, not both $LISA & $ROWAN

2) internal fees when executing trade. 
Uniswap has an external fee. One time fee for executing trade, no matter the size. This is called CFMM. Internal fee means to add the transaction fee in the model so big trade = big fees. Called CLP model, inspired by @thorchain_org

About trading:

And that's just the beginning. We aren't even talking about

- tokens as a coordination tool in a platform w distributed content
- tokens as an incentive with current value and future value
- governance mechanisms by people, powered by tokens

How tokens help with solutions:

1. Consensus-based decision making mechanism
2. Decision made by users, action executed by machines (smart contracts)
3. Burning stake = losing money

Solutions:

1. Content moderation by the community to decide what to post
2. "What to maximise" is a community-made decision. E.g. we can balance between ethics and revenue.
3. Policing of fake content/information/data

How tokens and distributed ecosystems/platforms are powerful.

Problem today: Section 230 in US laws protecting platforms. Anyone can post what they want. It's up to the platform *in good faith* to moderate. 

Solution: transferring power by the platform to community

Factors that cause the economic shift: 
1) New resource: information good 
2) Zero marginal cost in producing good 
3) Abundance of information good: using it does not diminish its value add + the ability of many to use it concurrently 
4) 1 + 1 = 3, without physical constraints
Nothing wrong with zero sum. Itâ€™s just that the alternative of positive sum is more attractive. And the alternative exists.
In the digital world: I have an intangible resource (idea, information, protocol) and you have an intangible resource. We come together and produce something. Itâ€™s positive sum.
In the physical world: I have gold coin and you have a cake. We trade and I have a cake and you have a coin. Itâ€™s zero sum.
The greatest development in the digital space (eg crypto) is the move from a zero sum trade to a positive sum trade.

So how do we ALIGN these things that we already know. And APPLY them in new ways, learning from the experiences of the past and the now?

Don't think we cracked the code yet. Hopefully a step closer every day.
It's less so about "changing economics" as it is about using these foundational principles to channel them towards other types of optimisation that works for a larger social utility optimisation.

Economics evolves. But the foundational principles still exist. 

Incentives, disincentives & how it affects behaviours. 

Supply, demand and coordination are the secondary foundational principle.

What are we trading off in our optimisation function today? 
What short-run benefits are at the expense of long-run costs because humans are flawed and we don't make decisions based on tomorrow, mainly based on the now?

The system today is messed up. We all know that. It isn't exactly a groundbreaking statement.

But... WHY?

Because incentives are misaligned. We also optimise for 1 measurable thing (usually money). There's nothing wrong w money and capitalism in its core, but its the trade-offs

Listen, this is what economics design is all about. It's about aligning incentives between agents. With or without tokens (aka the incentive). And the economic rules to align incentives and coordinate trade-offs.

And that is how we are building our future of tmr.

5. 5G & blockchain

DLT trx:
1. Block size (that means each car can only carry 2 people. Not more even if you have big roads)
2. Validation time (BTC is 10min)

5G is to send a fast car w V8 engine across. But if your car only has 2 people (vs mini van), bruh it still slow AF

5G is to make that "different wave frequency" much faster. So you transmit the 1 & 0 faster. 

The light pulse thing... well it's the speed of light right? Can't go faster than that.......for now.

4. How is data....transmitted?
Data = byte
byte = 1 & 0
1 & 0 = different wave frequency
different wave frequency = laser light pulses
Those stuff goes through various mediums and get to your phone.

3. There's cables under the ocean right? What's the link with that? Cables under the ocean is like a sponge cake. 4G and 5G are the frosting and decorations on the cake. 4G is basic disgusting fondant. 5G is high quality buttercream frosting. 

So cables are still necessary

2. So.... sending more people (aka data) across. What's the deal with that? So you basically get a lot of information faster. Email notif, your defi degen HF trades, better quality data instead of crappy zoom video calls.

6.2 Some crypto behave like commodities. Like BTC. So commodities and crypto-commodities as another type of asset class. 

Perhaps #6 needs to be in 2 different new asset class categories.

6. Crypto as an asset now looks at the other things. 

6.1 Governance tokens that has some form of equity for voting + fixed-income like return structure. It fits into neither of the boxes, and hence creating this new asset class.
5. Crypto derivatives exist, and those derivatives that only represent and trade that underlying exposure is a derivative.

4. Crypto that represents property IRL or even digital art. An asset. It could also be tokenising real assets like vintage wine, vintage cars, perhaps. 

Although then, I have no idea who will buy it.

3. Crypto that represents P2P cash and payments. Again, *NOT GOVERNANCE like $YFI* More like $AMPL or $DAI. 

Although they are (soft) pegged to USD, so idk how that works.

2. Crypto that represents a bond. *NOT GOVERNANCE like $BOND* More like an NFT that represents the bond for you to get FI or some other structure. 

The purpose is getting a FI return. *Not transaction fees.*

1. If the crypto represents fractional ownership of assets, it's a stock/equity. 

(once SEC approves of the existence of such products)

Maybe 70% equity as regular equity and 30% in digital equity and listed on DEX. How cool!

3. Cash/money makerts

Economics/geometric rules: we know that long-run optimisation is possible. So we have to define the short-run rules of the structure/pattern of how transactions link to each other (aka geometric vertices)

A very far fetched idea: a multi-dimensional Layer 1 DLT structure (vs 2D structure) w long-range optimisation that we see in many infinite patterns of quasicrystals, molecules and atoms. 

How: Rules for vertices (aka transactions)
Why: solve scalability problem

Iâ€™m all for free markets, but I donâ€™t believe in 100% Laissez-faire model. There needs to be a balance of free market and some government intervention bc markets are unfortunately short sighted and time sensitive.
Thatâ€™s not to say government doesnâ€™t play an important role. But at that unique point in time, markets had a huge power bc they were able and willing to consume (aka demand).

After WW2, people are tired and ready to embrace normal life again. Theyâ€™re willing to consume, spend, demand. And at that point, it makes sense to want free markets bc people (the market) has a high willingness to respond.

#Ponzinomics in DeFi is to 
(1) use shitty tokens as collaterals 
(2) use tokens as collaterals to create new tokens to be used as collaterals for other tokens to create collaterals. Maybe it's not 100% ponzi, but it smells, looks and kinda tastes like ponzi. <- increase demand

Funds run highly leveraged positions > Funds use (shitty?) stocks/bonds to get UST > BC best collateral is US treasury. Get maximum leverage w UST > and custody banks do this trade = getting paid to do this 

Hence, demand for UST even when yield is a big sad face
#Ponzinomics in traditional finance is to use shitty junk bonds and crappy scamy securities to be part of the collaterals. Default happens, collaterals are worth nothing, hello GFC.

Collateral is an economy on its own. For the economy to grow, you kinda need more collaterals so it is redistributed throughout the whole lending/borrowing/repo market. Like R. Ratio in banks.

Instead of multiplier effect in econs, it's a collateral multiplier effect in lending.

Let's talk #REPO market. Because that's the funding market in the world. Think of SUM(AAVE + MAKER + dYdX) multiple 10000000. 

(OK, it's slightly different bc in the repo market, it's gov securities. But the idea is using assets as collateral to borrow against it.)

You think think whole DeFi thing of "using this as collateral to mint that to use it as collateral" is #ponzinomics? Tell you what: traditional finance works just like that.

In English: if you don't aren't adding value, society knows. 

And well, what society does with people not adding value is the next problem in the future that we're building. ğŸ™ƒ 

It's a big problem. It keeps me up at night.
If you're not ahead on this train, driving it, it just highlights where you stand in the utility function, with you being an independent utility provider of this social optimisation function.
Wtf does this mean? We are self-selecting for the most productive and efficient outputs to drive the design and building of our future. Together.

Because the market selects the most efficient output (protocol, information, etc.) but at the same time, the network effect and tacit knowledge builds a natural barrier to entry for it to be replicated without any improvements.

Blockchain emphasises this effect. Information economy emphasises that. Open-source web 3.0 protocols emphasises that. 

And this is a brilliant thing.
The key difference in this zero marginal cost society is that things (outputs) are replicated easily but tacit knowledge and networks (inputs) are not.

Next step: 
combining (1) and (2) above. So you have 1 side of volatile asset (aka exposure. aka risk) and the other side is of low volatility. 

And that's the AMM mechanism for StableCredit at @iearnfinance

What we've seen in the space so far: 
1) AMM with volatile assets (ETH-CRV pairing, COMP-SUSHI pairing, etc) 
2) AMM with similar assets (Curve pools)

Benefit of low volatility: reduce risks of impermanent loss

How to achieve that: asset with a less volatility risk

These are multi-sided bonding curves. Meaning all assets are subjected to volatility. Except @CurveFinance, since they use similar assets in their bonding curve. 

E.g. wBTC, sBTC, pBTC <- basically all BTC. aka similar assets
sUSD, TUSD, USDT, renUSD <- basically all USD

7) Now, how does it apply to yield farming? Bc this information and system has no economic value if people don't use it, right? 

(A) Use that new stable asset to be doing your whatever farming field. Like a fertiliser. 
(B) Reduces vol with the stability, so easy to cal returns

6) Now, question. What does that.... stable asset do then? 

Simple.
(A) you get to collect the collaterals in the AMM
(B) you get to use it in the #defi system bc it's pegged and has value. E.g. use it to borrow assets in Yearn.

5.5) Combine (3) and (4), you realise that the asset will move quite a bit right? And when that happens, you have this thing called impermanent loss. 

Impermanent loss is a bad thing. Bad for asset holders in the AMM, can be bad for traders. So reduce this by reducing vol.
5) Another point on the stable asset in the single-sided AMM: this helps to reduce (remove, maybe? I can't justify if it removes it for real) impermanent loss when trading.

4) Lastly, it uses @AmpleforthOrg's model of tapping into secondary market for traders to do arbitrage to get the pegged value back to its ideal state. 

Why would they do that? Bc traders get to make money. Duh. 

Win-win-win.

3.5) Now, @iearnfinance goes a little further and say, "ok we don't want this new native token to be traded in the secondary market. Bc volatility sucks. So what can we do?" 

Simple. We make that new native token a stable token with a pegged value. Which brings us to (4)

3) How does the INTERNAL economy work then? It uses a single-sided AMM to mint the tokens. Confused? Think of it as @Bancor but BNT (the native token of Bancor) is not traded in the secondary market. So you reduce exposure for fluctuation.
2) Using @AaveAave's lending protocol so you can borrow up to 75% of the collaterals you provided (see 1 above)

If i can sum it up, it is combining 4 existing projects together: 

1) Using @MakerDAO's model of multi-collateral in the system, instead of just single asset collateral. You can put whatever asset you want as collaterals.

In fiscal policy, we analyse 2 things - spending (allocation of tokens) and revenue (aka taxes. aka transaction fees in #defi)

Back to the #defi space, we are employing machines (smart contracts) to automate the monetary policy side. 

So interest rates, supply, etc.
Projects: @AaveAave @compoundfinance @AmpleforthOrg 

It got me thinking. Where is the fiscal policy in #DeFi?!
Fiscal policy is the management of how money is being used within the system. It's the *governance* of money.

Alright nerd out with me here. 

Monetary policy is how the value of the system is managed. It could be a currency, a token, money. Whatever that represents value. 

So increasing or decreasing supply, interest rates, etc. Money stuff, y'know.

@tkpearson Thatâ€™s a very valid point - one that I discuss often. So what Iâ€™ve been doing for years now, is to have open conversations with young minds to find out what motivates them or pique their interest. Our education system is (so fking) flawed but we can leverage its benefits

@tkpearson But who is to say you canâ€™t be both studying AND starting your own biz? Itâ€™s not a binary choice. Many are working and studying. Itâ€™s like the best deal ever - with the 3-4 years time, you gain both education & job exp!

7/ In any case, education does not stop after school. Research is being done every day and you should be learning something every day. Books, youtube, podcast, research papers. 

Knowledge has a compounded effect too. 1.01*365 = 37.78. 1% learning every day compounded is big ğŸ’“

6/ Oh caveat, most people who "drop out and became successful" are not dropping out of random university degrees, you know that right? They got into a fantastic uni and the courses taught are beneath them.
5/ So, university is not completely redundant. There is a huge value beyond that dumb certificate. It builds your foundational knowledge and helps you specialise better (& faster) in your field.
4/ The network. Not just amongst your peers, but your profs, the research assistants, etc. My still good friends w my profs. (And I'm still asking them so many questions lol)
3/ It teaches you time management and perseverance. The soft skills learnt in university is so crucial that I think many are forgetting. Ofc, there are other soft skills

2/ It gave me better foundations to expand post-graduation. THIS IS SO IMPORTANT. For more technical subjects, you have to start with good foundations to build upon new ideas in the future. (i.e. economics -> economics of tokenisation and org design + industrial econs)

1/ If you know what you want, university gives you a fantastic head start. I always love economics. My econs degree and chats with my profs gave me new insights to look at matters. Things that I wouldn't learn just by reading research papers. Shapes my thought process.

Watch the full episode ğŸ‘‰ğŸ» EP 14: Why Bitcoin will NEVER be an international currency https://t.co/fCFexb9Sa6 

Also in it, a recap of the international monetary order, as well as its various failures. You can bet your life that in 2020, we are still talking about #BrettonWoods

In today's world, we have $BTC, or they like to call it #DigitalGold. Could it help us to teleport back to 1897 and use #Bitcoin to back our money? No. 

Why? (1) issue with monetary base expansion, (2) lack of price stability
We did that with gold and then with USD. Worked well, but it wasn't all rainbow and butterflies. It failed somewhere down the line.

Long answer: looking at the various #InternationalMonetaryOrder that the world has experienced since 1897, there were lots of failures. But the key lesson is that we need a nominal anchor (1 country or asset like gold to do that) as a way to stabilise financial markets.

New episode out! Why #Bitcoin will never be an #internationalcurrency. 

Short answer: because its automated monetary policy does not have a nominal anchor and thus does not strive for price nor financial stability. /Thread

Thus, the correlation of monetary inflation causes price inflation does not hold. In the same way, monetary deflation does not cause price deflation. And since that is the common view of the $BTC community, we are all wrong.

However, does that correlation always hold? Nah, one cannot argue so. Case in point: #2008GFC. 
The reduction in federal rates and instruments by the FED resulted in monetary inflation (increase in money supply). BUT it did not result in the same amount of price inflation

Economists have a fear of the massive increase in monetary inflation (printing money and central banks going #brr) results in price inflation of goods and services. That is not incorrect. That is exactly how hyperinflation came out. Case in point: Zimbabwe. Or Venezuela
Anyway, that means monetary inflation and price inflation are 2 different measures. Are they the same? No. Are they correlated? Maybe.
Price inflation is calculated using CPI or PCE. We generally use CPI to calculate the general inflation, whilst central banks use PCE to calculate their nominal anchor for monetary policy adjustment.
Bitcoin does have a monetary #disinflation variable (it is not even deflation). That means to increase its supply at a reduced rate.
Monetary inflation is the increase in money supply. Whilst price inflation is the increase in value of the basket of goods.

7/ Ultimate goal: better measurement of true productivity growth. 

Why? Bc intangible assets/capital are becoming an increasingly important (& significant) aspect of economic activity.

6/ Bunch of intangible things that is not accounted for in balance sheets: integrate GPT into the organisation, new biz process, managerial know-how, training workers, patch software, build other intangibles/synergies created.

5/ Problem? They require large intangible and unmeasured investments & fundamental rethinking of the tech. 

So? Usual measurement for productivity growth doesn't consider this*! 

(this* = tech changes the production function itself.)

4/ What is GPT? They are "engines for growth". Pervasive, improve over time, lead to complementary innovation. They can radically change our economic environment.
E.g. electricity, internet, AI, distributed ledger tech.

3/ (2) in the ever-changing world economy, we are moving towards digitisation, where things are getting more intangible (E.g. know-how, r&d). We need to start considering them properly account for their significance.

2/ Why is it important to consider intangibles? (1) Because intangibles are part of #PRODUCTIVITY, we all know that. But for some reason, they are not truly accounted for in statistics, GDP, balance sheets.

8/ Paper: Automation and New Tasks: How Technology Displaces and Reinstates Labor By Acemoglu, Restrepo https://t.co/eS1hC89Vzy
7/ The creation of new tasks and other technologies raising the labor intensity of production and the labor share are vital for continued wage growth commensurate with productivity growth.

6/ Automation by itself always reduces the labor share in industry value added and tends to reduce the overall labor share in the economy (meaning that it leads to slower wage growth than productivity growth). On net, labor retained a key role in production.

5/ Honestly, 4/ is just the result of efficient market and evolution of capitalism. With capitalism, owners seek to look for increase in productivity gains while reducing costs, and substituting workers with cheaper automated tech makes absolute efficient sense.

4/ Some automation technologies may in fact reduce labor demand because they bring sizable displacement effects but modest productivity gains (especially when substituted workers were cheap to begin with and the automated technology is only marginally better than them).
3/ Instead, the displacement effect of automation has been counterbalanced by technologies that create new tasks in which labor has a comparative advantage.

2/ The displacement effect implies that automation reduces the labor share of value added. The net impact of automation on labor demand thus depends on how the displacement and productivity effects weigh against each other.
1/ Automation and Labour Effect: Automation changes the task content of production adversely for labor because of a displacement effectâ€”as capital takes over tasks previously performed by labor.

15/ Link to paper - https://t.co/x8TFVjpWeM by the @BostonFed

14/ Your takeaway as a central banker/policy maker: Most monetary policy considers traditional formal employment to understand market movements but that is not holistic enough. Include the new form of work - informal work that are full-time equivalent.
12/ (5) Schedule flexibility is rather crucial in the choosing of informal vs formal jobs

11/ (4) relatively weak wage inflation (aka wage increase) tend to have more "low-wage" information full-time equivalent (aka these people could have been working traditional formal full-time work and earn more wages)

10/ (3) Important to consider informal work as a significant component to the market labour force because traditional unemployment rates (as mentioned in 7/) can help explain why wage inflation is more in some places than others
9/ (2) people view informal and formal work as substitutes
8/ Summary of paper: (1) more informal work = less wage inflation (against the traditional theory as we know it, the Phillips Curve)

7/ (continued) The paper talked about 2 types of unemployment rates U3 & U6. U3 = your traditional unemployment rate. U6 = U3 + other types of people like  discouraged, underemployed, and unemployed workers. (So, U6 incudes more people in the pool)
